facts.text: Appeal filed as Criminal Appeal No. 101 of 1972 in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 101 of 1972. Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and order dated the 25th February, 1972 of the Rajasthan High Court at Jodhpur in S. B. Criminal Revision No. 52 of 1972.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated 25th February 1972 of Rajasthan High Court at Jodhpur in S.B. Criminal Revision No. 52 of 1972.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and order dated the 25th February, 1972 of the Rajasthan High Court at Jodhpur in S. B. Criminal Revision No. 52 of 1972. D. Sharma, S. K. Bagga, S. Bagga, Rani Arora and Yash Bagga, for the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant filed complaint against 2nd respondent before Add. Munsiff Magistrate of Jodhpur City under sections 323 and 504 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed a companyplaint against the 2nd respondent before the Add. Munsiff Magistrate of Jodhpur City under ss. 323 and 504 I.P.C. The 2nd respondent was the Post Master General, Rajasthan and the appellant a clerk in the Head Post Office at Jodhpur.

facts.text: 2nd respondent was Post Master General, Rajasthan.

anchor.surface_text: The 2nd respondent was the Post Master General, Rajasthan and the appellant a clerk in the Head Post Office at Jodhpur. He was also the, Divisional Secretary of National Union of Postal Employees.

facts.text: Appellant was a clerk in the Head Post Office at Jodhpur and Divisional Secretary of National Union of Postal Employees.

anchor.surface_text: The 2nd respondent was the Post Master General, Rajasthan and the appellant a clerk in the Head Post Office at Jodhpur. He was also the, Divisional Secretary of National Union of Postal Employees. The relevant portion of the companyplaint is as follows 4, That the accused came on tour to Jodhpur on 25-10-1971.

facts.text: Accused came on tour to Jodhpur on 25-10-1971.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant portion of the companyplaint is as follows 4, That the accused came on tour to Jodhpur on 25-10-1971. He arrived at the Head Post Office Jodhpur, in companynection with the inspection at 5.45 P.M.

facts.text: Accused arrived at Head Post Office Jodhpur at 5.45 P.M. in connection with inspection.

anchor.surface_text: That the accused came on tour to Jodhpur on 25-10-1971. He arrived at the Head Post Office Jodhpur, in companynection with the inspection at 5.45 P.M. The companyplainant reached to submit his representation to the accused for cancelling his transfer, when.

facts.text: Complainant reached to submit representation to accused for cancelling his transfer.

anchor.surface_text: He arrived at the Head Post Office Jodhpur, in companynection with the inspection at 5.45 P.M. The companyplainant reached to submit his representation to the accused for cancelling his transfer, when. the accused just sat in his jeep and the companyplainant started narrating his story.

facts.text: Accused sat in his jeep and complainant started narrating his story.

anchor.surface_text: The companyplainant reached to submit his representation to the accused for cancelling his transfer, when. the accused just sat in his jeep and the companyplainant started narrating his story. That the accused being enraged by this companyplaint, kicked him in his abdomen and abused him by saying Sale, Goonda, Badmash,

facts.text: Accused kicked complainant in his abdomen.

anchor.surface_text: That the accused being enraged by this companyplaint, kicked him in his abdomen and abused him by saying Sale, Goonda, Badmash, on one hand you are companyplaining and on the other hand you are requesting for the cancellation of transfer.

facts.text: Accused abused complainant saying 'Sale, Goonda, Badmash, on one hand you are complaining and on the other hand you are requesting for the cancellation of transfer.'

facts.text: Complainant became enraged but suppressed his anger as responsible citizen to avoid disturbance.

anchor.surface_text: on the other hand you are requesting for the cancellation of transfer. That the companyplainant became very much enraged over this incident but he suppressed his anger because of being responsible citizen and to avoid any further disturbance. That after kicking and abusing the companyplainant the accused ran away in his jeep.

facts.text: After kicking and abusing, accused ran away in his jeep.

anchor.surface_text: he suppressed his anger because of being responsible citizen and to avoid any further disturbance. The 2nd respondent filed an application under S. 197 of the Code of Criminal Procedure praying that the companyrt should number take companynizance of the offence without the sanction of the Government

facts.text: 2nd respondent filed application under S. 197 CrPC praying court should not take cognizance without sanction of Government, as acts done while discharging duties as public servant.

anchor.surface_text: The 2nd respondent filed an application under S. 197 of the Code of Criminal Procedure praying that the companyrt should number take companynizance of the offence without the sanction of the Government as the acts alleged, if at all done by the accused, were done while discharging his duties as a public servant.

facts.text: Munsiff Magistrate dismissed the application under S. 197 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: The Munsiff Magistrate dismissed the application but Justice Mehta of the Rajasthan High Court allowed the revision petition filed by the 2nd respondent and set aside the order of the lower companyrt holding that the 2nd respondent companyld number be prosecuted unless prior sanction of the Central Government had been obtained.

facts.text: Justice Mehta of Rajasthan High Court allowed revision petition filed by 2nd respondent and set aside order of lower court.

anchor.surface_text: The Munsiff Magistrate dismissed the application but Justice Mehta of the Rajasthan High Court allowed the revision petition filed by the 2nd respondent and set aside the order of the lower companyrt holding that the 2nd respondent companyld number be prosecuted unless prior sanction of the Central Government had been obtained. This appeal is against that order.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court held that 2nd respondent could not be prosecuted without prior sanction of Central Government.

anchor.surface_text: set aside the order of the lower companyrt holding that the 2nd respondent companyld number be prosecuted unless prior sanction of the Central Government had been obtained. facts.text: Appeal is against the order of Rajasthan High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is against that order. The law regarding the circumstances under which sanction under s.197 of the Code of Criminal Procedure is necessary is by number well settled as result of the decisions from Hori Ram Singhs 1  case to the latest decision of this Court in Bhagwan Prasad Srivastava v. N. P. Misra.

anchor.surface_text: But facts subsequently companying to light during the companyrse of the judicial inquiry or during the companyrse of the prosecution evidence at the trial may establish the necessity for sanction. Whether sanction is necessary or number may have for depend from stage to stage.

concepts.interpretation: The intention behind the section is to prevent public servants from being unnecessarily harassed. The section is not restricted only to cases of anything purported to be done in good faith... The offence should have been committed when an act is done in the execution of duty or when an act purports to be done in the execution of duty.

arguments.court_reasoning: Acts alleged not in purported exercise of duty; difficult to say they were in course of performance of duty.

arguments.claim: Sanction under s.197 CrPC is not necessary as the acts complained of (kicking and abusing) could not be said to have been done in the course of performance of the 2nd respondent's duty.

anchor.surface_text: There must be a reasonable connection between the act and the discharge of official duty the act must bear such relation to the duty that the accused could lay a reasonable, but not a pretended or fanciful claim, that he did it in the course of the performance of his duty. Applying this test it is difficult to say that the acts complained of i.e. of kicking the complainant and of abusing him, could be said to have been done in the, course of performance of the 2nd respondents duty.

arguments.claim: On the facts alleged in the complaint, what the 2nd respondent is alleged to have done could not be said to be in purported exercise of his duty.

anchor.surface_text: At this stage all that we are concerned with is whether on the facts alleged in the complaint it could be said that what the 2nd respondent is alleged to have done could be said to be in purported exercise of his duty. Very clearly it is not.

arguments.claim: The intention behind s.197 is to prevent public servants from being unnecessarily harassed; section not restricted to acts done in good faith or where offence is official duty.

anchor.surface_text: The intention behind the section is to prevent public servants from being unnecessarily harassed. The section is not restricted only to cases of anything purported to be done in good faith, for a person who ostensibly acts in execution of his duty still purports so to act, although he may have a dishonest intention.

arguments.claim: Offence must be committed by public servant in an act done or purporting to be done in execution of duty; not confined to acts directly in pursuance of office or inseparably connected.

anchor.surface_text: Nor is it confined to cases where the act, which constitutes the offence, is the official duty of the official concerned. Such an interpretation would involve a contradiction in terms, because an offence can never be an official duty. The offence should have been committed when an act is done in the execution of duty or when an act purports to be done in the execution of duty.

arguments.claim: Test for s.197: reasonable connection between act and discharge of official duty such that accused could lay reasonable claim it was in performance of duty (from Matajog Dobey).

anchor.surface_text: The test appears to be not that the offence is capable of being committed only, by a public servant and not anyone else, but that it is committed by a public servant in an act done or purporting to be done in the execution of his duty. ... There must be a reasonable connection between the act and the discharge of official duty the act must bear such relation to the duty that the accused could lay a reasonable, but not a pretended or fanciful claim, that he did it in the course of the performance of his duty.

arguments.claim: Public servant acts in discharge of duty if act lies within scope of official duty and he can reasonably claim to do it in virtue of office (from Hori Ram Singh).

anchor.surface_text: the test may well be whether the public servant, if challenged, can reasonably claim that, what he does, he does in virtue of his office.

arguments.claim: Necessity for sanction may depend on facts emerging later during inquiry or trial; may vary from stage to stage.

anchor.surface_text: But facts subsequently coming to light during the course of the judicial inquiry or during the course of the prosecution evidence at the trial may establish the necessity for sanction. Whether sanction is necessary or not may have to depend from stage to stage.

precedents.cited_proposition: circumstances under which sanction under s.197 CrPC is necessary; section not confined to acts directly in pursuance of duty or inseparably connected; there must be something in nature of act attaching it to official character
precedents.cited_holding: The section cannot be confined to only such acts as are done by a public servant directly in pursuance of his public office, though in excess of the duty or under a mistaken belief as to the existence of such duty. Nor is it necessary to go to the length of saying that the act constituting the offence should be so inseparably connected with the official duty as to form part and parcel of the same transaction. there must be something in the nature of the act complained of that attaches it to the official character of the person doing it.

precedents.citation: Bhagwan Prasad Srivastava v. N. P. Misra.  2

anchor.surface_text: the latest decision of this Court in Bhagwan Prasad Srivastava v. N. P. precedents.cited_holding: A public servant can only be said to act or purport to act in the discharge of his official duty, if his act is such as to lie within the scope of his official duty The test may well be whether the public servant, if challenged, can reasonably claim that, what he does, he does in virtue of his office.

anchor.surface_text: In Matajog Dobey v. H. C. Bhari 2  the Court was of the view that the test laid down that it must be established that the act complained of was an official act unduly narrowed down the scope of the protection afforded by section 197.
